sn22.84:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Tissa—the Buddha’s cousin on his father’s side—informed several mendicants:
sn22.84:1.3: “Reverends, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”
sn22.84:2.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
sn22.84:3.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
sn22.84:3.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Tissa that the Teacher summons him.”
sn22.84:3.3: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Tissa and said to him,
sn22.84:3.5: “Yes, reverend,” Tissa replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
sn22.84:3.6: “Is it really true, Tissa, that you informed several mendicants that
sn22.84:3.7: your body feels like it’s drugged … and you have doubts about the teachings?”
sn22.84:3.10: If you’re not rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:4.3: when you’re not rid of greed for form.
sn22.84:4.4: If you’re not rid of greed for feeling …
sn22.84:5.3: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:6.3: when you’re not rid of greed for consciousness.
sn22.84:6.5: If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:7.3: when you are rid of greed for form …
sn22.84:8.14: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
sn22.84:9.1: Suppose, Tissa, there were two individuals.
sn22.84:9.2: One was not skilled in the path, the other was.
sn22.84:9.3: The one not skilled in the path would question the one skilled in the path,
sn22.84:9.5: ‘Come, good man, this is the path.
sn22.84:9.7: and you’ll see a fork in the road. Ignore the left, and take the right-hand path.
sn22.84:9.9: and you’ll see a dense forest grove.
sn22.84:9.11: and you’ll see an expanse of low-lying marshes.
sn22.84:9.13: and you’ll see a large, steep cliff.
sn22.84:9.15: and you’ll see level, cleared parkland.’
sn22.84:10.1: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
sn22.84:10.2: And this is what it means.
sn22.84:10.3: ‘A person who is not skilled in the path’ is a term for an ordinary unlearned person.
sn22.84:10.4: ‘A person who is skilled in the path’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
sn22.84:10.5: ‘A fork in the road’ is a term for doubt.
sn22.84:10.6: ‘The left-hand path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,
sn22.84:10.8: ‘The right-hand path’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is,
sn22.84:10.10: ‘A dense forest grove’ is a term for ignorance.
sn22.84:10.11: ‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
sn22.84:10.12: ‘A large, steep cliff’ is a term for anger and distress.
sn22.84:10.13: ‘Level, cleared parkland’ is a term for extinguishment.
sn22.84:10.15: I am here with advice, with support, with instruction.”
sn22.84:11.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn22.84:11.2: Satisfied, Venerable Tissa approved what the Buddha said.
